items.name: AccountNonce
docs: Extrinsics nonce for accounts.

items.name: ExtrinsicCount
docs: Total extrinsics count for the current block.

items.name: AllExtrinsicsWeight
docs: Total weight for all extrinsics put together, for the current block.

items.name: AllExtrinsicsLen
docs: Total length (in bytes) for all extrinsics put together, for the current block.

items.name: BlockHash
docs: Map of block numbers to block hashes.

items.name: ExtrinsicData
docs: Extrinsics data for the current block (maps an extrinsic's index to its data).

items.name: Number
docs: The current block number being processed. Set by `execute_block`.

items.name: ParentHash
docs: Hash of the previous block.

items.name: ExtrinsicsRoot
docs: Extrinsics root of the current block, also part of the block header.

items.name: Digest
docs: Digest of the current block, also part of the block header.

items.name: Events
docs: Events deposited for the current block.

items.name: EventCount
docs: The number of events in the `Events<T>` list.

items.name: EventTopics
docs: Mapping between a topic (represented by T::Hash) and a vector of indexes
of events in the `<Events<T>>` list.
The first key serves no purpose. This field is declared as double_map just
for convenience of using `remove_prefix`.
All topic vectors have deterministic storage locations depending on the topic. This
allows light-clients to leverage the changes trie storage tracking mechanism and
in case of changes fetch the list of events of interest.
The value has the type `(T::BlockNumber, EventIndex)` because if we used only just
the `EventIndex` then in case if the topic has the same contents on the next block
no notification will be triggered thus the event might be lost.

calls.name: fill_block
docs: A big dispatch that will disallow any other transaction to be included.

calls.name: remark
docs: Make some on-chain remark.

calls.name: set_heap_pages
docs: Set the number of pages in the WebAssembly environment's heap.

calls.name: set_code
docs: Set the new code.

calls.name: set_storage
docs: Set some items of storage.

calls.name: kill_storage
docs: Kill some items from storage.

calls.name: kill_prefix
docs: Kill all storage items with a key that starts with the given prefix.

events.name: ExtrinsicSuccess
docs: An extrinsic completed successfully.

events.name: ExtrinsicFailed
docs: An extrinsic failed.

calls.name: batch
docs: Send a batch of dispatch calls (only root).

items.name: EpochIndex
docs: Current epoch index.

items.name: Authorities
docs: Current epoch authorities.

items.name: GenesisSlot
docs: The slot at which the first epoch actually started. This is 0
until the first block of the chain.

items.name: CurrentSlot
docs: Current slot number.

items.name: Randomness
docs: The epoch randomness for the *current* epoch.
# Security
This MUST NOT be used for gambling, as it can be influenced by a
malicious validator in the short term. It MAY be used in many
cryptographic protocols, however, so long as one remembers that this
(like everything else on-chain) it is public. For example, it can be
used where a number is needed that cannot have been chosen by an
adversary, for purposes such as public-coin zero-knowledge proofs.

items.name: NextRandomness
docs: Next epoch randomness.

items.name: SegmentIndex
docs: Randomness under construction.
We make a tradeoff between storage accesses and list length.
We store the under-construction randomness in segments of up to
`UNDER_CONSTRUCTION_SEGMENT_LENGTH`.
Once a segment reaches this length, we begin the next one.
We reset all segments and return to `0` at the beginning of every
epoch.

items.name: Initialized
docs: Temporary value (cleared at block finalization) which is `Some`
if per-block initialization has already been called for current block.

constants.name: EpochDuration
docs: The number of **slots** that an epoch takes. We couple sessions to
epochs, i.e. we start a new session once the new epoch begins.

constants.name: ExpectedBlockTime
docs: The expected average block time at which BABE should be creating
blocks. Since BABE is probabilistic it is not trivial to figure out
what the expected average block time should be based on the slot
duration and the security parameter `c` (where `1 - c` represents
the probability of a slot being empty).

items.name: Now
docs: Current time for the current block.

items.name: DidUpdate
docs: Did the timestamp get updated in this block?

calls.name: set
docs: Set the current time.
This call should be invoked exactly once per block. It will panic at the finalization
phase, if this call hasn't been invoked by that time.
The timestamp should be greater than the previous one by the amount specified by
`MinimumPeriod`.
The dispatch origin for this call must be `Inherent`.

constants.name: MinimumPeriod
docs: The minimum period between blocks. Beware that this is different to the *expected* period
that the block production apparatus provides. Your chosen consensus system will generally
work with this to determine a sensible block time. e.g. For Aura, it will be double this
period on default settings.

items.name: Uncles
docs: Uncles

items.name: Author
docs: Author of current block.

items.name: DidSetUncles
docs: Whether uncles were already set in this block.

calls.name: set_uncles
docs: Provide a set of uncles.

items.name: NextEnumSet
docs: The next free enumeration set.

items.name: EnumSet
docs: The enumeration sets.

events.name: NewAccountIndex
docs: A new account index was assigned.
This event is not triggered when an existing index is reassigned
to another `AccountId`.

items.name: TotalIssuance
docs: The total units issued in the system.

items.name: Vesting
docs: Information regarding the vesting of a given account.

items.name: FreeBalance
docs: The 'free' balance of a given account.
This is the only balance that matters in terms of most operations on tokens. It
alone is used to determine the balance when in the contract execution environment. When this
balance falls below the value of `ExistentialDeposit`, then the 'current account' is
deleted: specifically `FreeBalance`. Further, the `OnFreeBalanceZero` callback
is invoked, giving a chance to external modules to clean up data associated with
the deleted account.
`system::AccountNonce` is also deleted if `ReservedBalance` is also zero (it also gets
collapsed to zero if it ever becomes less than `ExistentialDeposit`.

items.name: ReservedBalance
docs: The amount of the balance of a given account that is externally reserved; this can still get
slashed, but gets slashed last of all.
This balance is a 'reserve' balance that other subsystems use in order to set aside tokens
that are still 'owned' by the account holder, but which are suspendable.
When this balance falls below the value of `ExistentialDeposit`, then this 'reserve account'
is deleted: specifically, `ReservedBalance`.
`system::AccountNonce` is also deleted if `FreeBalance` is also zero (it also gets
collapsed to zero if it ever becomes less than `ExistentialDeposit`.)

items.name: Locks
docs: Any liquidity locks on some account balances.

calls.name: transfer
docs: Transfer some liquid free balance to another account.
`transfer` will set the `FreeBalance` of the sender and receiver.
It will decrease the total issuance of the system by the `TransferFee`.
If the sender's account is below the existential deposit as a result
of the transfer, the account will be reaped.
The dispatch origin for this call must be `Signed` by the transactor.
# <weight>
- Dependent on arguments but not critical, given proper implementations for
input config types. See related functions below.
- It contains a limited number of reads and writes internally and no complex computation.
Related functions:
- `ensure_can_withdraw` is always called internally but has a bounded complexity.
- Transferring balances to accounts that did not exist before will cause
`T::OnNewAccount::on_new_account` to be called.
- Removing enough funds from an account will trigger
`T::DustRemoval::on_unbalanced` and `T::OnFreeBalanceZero::on_free_balance_zero`.
- `transfer_keep_alive` works the same way as `transfer`, but has an additional
check that the transfer will not kill the origin account.
# </weight>

calls.name: set_balance
docs: Set the balances of a given account.
This will alter `FreeBalance` and `ReservedBalance` in storage. it will
also decrease the total issuance of the system (`TotalIssuance`).
If the new free or reserved balance is below the existential deposit,
it will reset the account nonce (`system::AccountNonce`).
The dispatch origin for this call is `root`.
# <weight>
- Independent of the arguments.
- Contains a limited number of reads and writes.
# </weight>

calls.name: force_transfer
docs: Exactly as `transfer`, except the origin must be root and the source account may be
specified.

calls.name: transfer_keep_alive
docs: Same as the [`transfer`] call, but with a check that the transfer will not kill the
origin account.
99% of the time you want [`transfer`] instead.
[`transfer`]: struct.Module.html#method.transfer

events.name: NewAccount
docs: A new account was created.

events.name: ReapedAccount
docs: An account was reaped.

events.name: Transfer
docs: Transfer succeeded (from, to, value, fees).

constants.name: ExistentialDeposit
docs: The minimum amount required to keep an account open.

constants.name: TransferFee
docs: The fee required to make a transfer.

constants.name: CreationFee
docs: The fee required to create an account.

constants.name: TransactionBaseFee
docs: The fee to be paid for making a transaction; the base.

constants.name: TransactionByteFee
docs: The fee to be paid for making a transaction; the per-byte portion.

items.name: ValidatorCount
docs: The ideal number of staking participants.

items.name: MinimumValidatorCount
docs: Minimum number of staking participants before emergency conditions are imposed.

items.name: Invulnerables
docs: Any validators that may never be slashed or forcibly kicked. It's a Vec since they're
easy to initialize and the performance hit is minimal (we expect no more than four
invulnerables) and restricted to testnets.

items.name: Bonded
docs: Map from all locked "stash" accounts to the controller account.

items.name: Ledger
docs: Map from all (unlocked) "controller" accounts to the info regarding the staking.

items.name: Payee
docs: Where the reward payment should be made. Keyed by stash.

items.name: Validators
docs: The map from (wannabe) validator stash key to the preferences of that validator.

items.name: Nominators
docs: The map from nominator stash key to the set of stash keys of all validators to nominate.
NOTE: is private so that we can ensure upgraded before all typical accesses.
Direct storage APIs can still bypass this protection.

items.name: Stakers
docs: Nominators for a particular account that is in action right now. You can't iterate
through validators here, but you can find them in the Session module.
This is keyed by the stash account.

items.name: CurrentElected
docs: The currently elected validator set keyed by stash account ID.

items.name: CurrentEra
docs: The current era index.

items.name: CurrentEraStart
docs: The start of the current era.

items.name: CurrentEraStartSessionIndex
docs: The session index at which the current era started.

items.name: CurrentEraPointsEarned
docs: Rewards for the current era. Using indices of current elected set.

items.name: SlotStake
docs: The amount of balance actively at stake for each validator slot, currently.
This is used to derive rewards and punishments.

items.name: ForceEra
docs: True if the next session change will be a new era regardless of index.

items.name: SlashRewardFraction
docs: The percentage of the slash that is distributed to reporters.
The rest of the slashed value is handled by the `Slash`.

items.name: CanceledSlashPayout
docs: The amount of currency given to reporters of a slash event which was
canceled by extraordinary circumstances (e.g. governance).

items.name: UnappliedSlashes
docs: All unapplied slashes that are queued for later.

items.name: BondedEras
docs: A mapping from still-bonded eras to the first session index of that era.

items.name: ValidatorSlashInEra
docs: All slashing events on validators, mapped by era to the highest slash proportion
and slash value of the era.

items.name: NominatorSlashInEra
docs: All slashing events on nominators, mapped by era to the highest slash value of the era.

items.name: SlashingSpans
docs: Slashing spans for stash accounts.

items.name: SpanSlash
docs: Records information about the maximum slash of a stash within a slashing span,
as well as how much reward has been paid out.

items.name: EarliestUnappliedSlash
docs: The earliest era for which we have a pending, unapplied slash.

items.name: StorageVersion
docs: The version of storage for upgrade.

calls.name: bond
docs: Take the origin account as a stash and lock up `value` of its balance. `controller` will
be the account that controls it.
`value` must be more than the `minimum_balance` specified by `T::Currency`.
The dispatch origin for this call must be _Signed_ by the stash account.
# <weight>
- Independent of the arguments. Moderate complexity.
- Three extra DB entries.
NOTE: Two of the storage writes (`Self::bonded`, `Self::payee`) are _never_ cleaned unless
the `origin` falls below _existential deposit_ and gets removed as dust.
# </weight>

calls.name: bond_extra
docs: Add some extra amount that have appeared in the stash `free_balance` into the balance up
for staking.
Use this if there are additional funds in your stash account that you wish to bond.
Unlike [`bond`] or [`unbond`] this function does not impose any limitation on the amount
that can be added.
The dispatch origin for this call must be _Signed_ by the stash, not the controller.
# <weight>
- Independent of the arguments. Insignificant complexity.
- One DB entry.
# </weight>

calls.name: unbond
docs: Schedule a portion of the stash to be unlocked ready for transfer out after the bond
period ends. If this leaves an amount actively bonded less than
T::Currency::minimum_balance(), then it is increased to the full amount.
Once the unlock period is done, you can call `withdraw_unbonded` to actually move
the funds out of management ready for transfer.
No more than a limited number of unlocking chunks (see `MAX_UNLOCKING_CHUNKS`)
can co-exists at the same time. In that case, [`Call::withdraw_unbonded`] need
to be called first to remove some of the chunks (if possible).
The dispatch origin for this call must be _Signed_ by the controller, not the stash.
See also [`Call::withdraw_unbonded`].
# <weight>
- Independent of the arguments. Limited but potentially exploitable complexity.
- Contains a limited number of reads.
- Each call (requires the remainder of the bonded balance to be above `minimum_balance`)
will cause a new entry to be inserted into a vector (`Ledger.unlocking`) kept in storage.
The only way to clean the aforementioned storage item is also user-controlled via `withdraw_unbonded`.
- One DB entry.
</weight>

calls.name: withdraw_unbonded
docs: Remove any unlocked chunks from the `unlocking` queue from our management.
This essentially frees up that balance to be used by the stash account to do
whatever it wants.
The dispatch origin for this call must be _Signed_ by the controller, not the stash.
See also [`Call::unbond`].
# <weight>
- Could be dependent on the `origin` argument and how much `unlocking` chunks exist.
It implies `consolidate_unlocked` which loops over `Ledger.unlocking`, which is
indirectly user-controlled. See [`unbond`] for more detail.
- Contains a limited number of reads, yet the size of which could be large based on `ledger`.
- Writes are limited to the `origin` account key.
# </weight>

calls.name: validate
docs: Declare the desire to validate for the origin controller.
Effects will be felt at the beginning of the next era.
The dispatch origin for this call must be _Signed_ by the controller, not the stash.
# <weight>
- Independent of the arguments. Insignificant complexity.
- Contains a limited number of reads.
- Writes are limited to the `origin` account key.
# </weight>

calls.name: nominate
docs: Declare the desire to nominate `targets` for the origin controller.
Effects will be felt at the beginning of the next era.
The dispatch origin for this call must be _Signed_ by the controller, not the stash.
# <weight>
- The transaction's complexity is proportional to the size of `targets`,
which is capped at `MAX_NOMINATIONS`.
- Both the reads and writes follow a similar pattern.
# </weight>

calls.name: chill
docs: Declare no desire to either validate or nominate.
Effects will be felt at the beginning of the next era.
The dispatch origin for this call must be _Signed_ by the controller, not the stash.
# <weight>
- Independent of the arguments. Insignificant complexity.
- Contains one read.
- Writes are limited to the `origin` account key.
# </weight>

calls.name: set_payee
docs: (Re-)set the payment target for a controller.
Effects will be felt at the beginning of the next era.
The dispatch origin for this call must be _Signed_ by the controller, not the stash.
# <weight>
- Independent of the arguments. Insignificant complexity.
- Contains a limited number of reads.
- Writes are limited to the `origin` account key.
# </weight>

calls.name: set_controller
docs: (Re-)set the controller of a stash.
Effects will be felt at the beginning of the next era.
The dispatch origin for this call must be _Signed_ by the stash, not the controller.
# <weight>
- Independent of the arguments. Insignificant complexity.
- Contains a limited number of reads.
- Writes are limited to the `origin` account key.
# </weight>

calls.name: set_validator_count
docs: The ideal number of validators.

calls.name: force_no_eras
docs: Force there to be no new eras indefinitely.
# <weight>
- No arguments.
# </weight>

calls.name: force_new_era
docs: Force there to be a new era at the end of the next session. After this, it will be
reset to normal (non-forced) behaviour.
# <weight>
- No arguments.
# </weight>

calls.name: set_invulnerables
docs: Set the validators who cannot be slashed (if any).

calls.name: force_unstake
docs: Force a current staker to become completely unstaked, immediately.

calls.name: force_new_era_always
docs: Force there to be a new era at the end of sessions indefinitely.
# <weight>
- One storage write
# </weight>

calls.name: cancel_deferred_slash
docs: Cancel enactment of a deferred slash. Can be called by either the root origin or
the `T::SlashCancelOrigin`.
passing the era and indices of the slashes for that era to kill.
# <weight>
- One storage write.
# </weight>

events.name: Reward
docs: All validators have been rewarded by the first balance; the second is the remainder
from the maximum amount of reward.

events.name: Slash
docs: One validator (and its nominators) has been slashed by the given amount.

events.name: OldSlashingReportDiscarded
docs: An old slashing report from a prior era was discarded because it could
not be processed.

constants.name: SessionsPerEra
docs: Number of sessions per era.

constants.name: BondingDuration
docs: Number of eras that staked funds must remain bonded for.

items.name: Validators
docs: The current set of validators.

items.name: CurrentIndex
docs: Current index of the session.

items.name: QueuedChanged
docs: True if the underlying economic identities or weighting behind the validators
has changed in the queued validator set.

items.name: QueuedKeys
docs: The queued keys for the next session. When the next session begins, these keys
will be used to determine the validator's session keys.

items.name: DisabledValidators
docs: Indices of disabled validators.
The set is cleared when `on_session_ending` returns a new set of identities.

items.name: NextKeys
docs: The next session keys for a validator.
The first key is always `DEDUP_KEY_PREFIX` to have all the data in the same branch of
the trie. Having all data in the same branch should prevent slowing down other queries.

items.name: KeyOwner
docs: The owner of a key. The second key is the `KeyTypeId` + the encoded key.
The first key is always `DEDUP_KEY_PREFIX` to have all the data in the same branch of
the trie. Having all data in the same branch should prevent slowing down other queries.

calls.name: set_keys
docs: Sets the session key(s) of the function caller to `key`.
Allows an account to set its session key prior to becoming a validator.
This doesn't take effect until the next session.
The dispatch origin of this function must be signed.
# <weight>
- O(log n) in number of accounts.
- One extra DB entry.
# </weight>

events.name: NewSession
docs: New session has happened. Note that the argument is the session index, not the block
number as the type might suggest.

constants.name: DEDUP_KEY_PREFIX
docs: Used as first key for `NextKeys` and `KeyOwner` to put all the data into the same branch
of the trie.

items.name: PublicPropCount
docs: The number of (public) proposals that have been made so far.

items.name: PublicProps
docs: The public proposals. Unsorted. The second item is the proposal's hash.

items.name: Preimages
docs: Map of hashes to the proposal preimage, along with who registered it and their deposit.
The block number is the block at which it was deposited.

items.name: DepositOf
docs: Those who have locked a deposit.

items.name: ReferendumCount
docs: The next free referendum index, aka the number of referenda started so far.

items.name: NextTally
docs: The next referendum index that should be tallied.

items.name: ReferendumInfoOf
docs: Information concerning any given referendum.

items.name: DispatchQueue
docs: Queue of successful referenda to be dispatched.

items.name: VotersFor
docs: Get the voters for the current proposal.

items.name: VoteOf
docs: Get the vote in a given referendum of a particular voter. The result is meaningful only
if `voters_for` includes the voter when called with the referendum (you'll get the
default `Vote` value otherwise). If you don't want to check `voters_for`, then you can
also check for simple existence with `VoteOf::exists` first.

items.name: Proxy
docs: Who is able to vote for whom. Value is the fund-holding account, key is the
vote-transaction-sending account.

items.name: Delegations
docs: Get the account (and lock periods) to which another account is delegating vote.

items.name: LastTabledWasExternal
docs: True if the last referendum tabled was submitted externally. False if it was a public
proposal.

items.name: NextExternal
docs: The referendum to be tabled whenever it would be valid to table an external proposal.
This happens when a referendum needs to be tabled and one of two conditions are met:
- `LastTabledWasExternal` is `false`; or
- `PublicProps` is empty.

items.name: Blacklist
docs: A record of who vetoed what. Maps proposal hash to a possible existent block number
(until when it may not be resubmitted) and who vetoed it.

items.name: Cancellations
docs: Record of all proposals that have been subject to emergency cancellation.

calls.name: propose
docs: Propose a sensitive action to be taken.
# <weight>
- Two DB changes, one DB entry.
# </weight>

calls.name: second
docs: Propose a sensitive action to be taken.
# <weight>
- One DB entry.
# </weight>

calls.name: vote
docs: Vote in a referendum. If `vote.is_aye()`, the vote is to enact the proposal;
otherwise it is a vote to keep the status quo.
# <weight>
- One DB change, one DB entry.
# </weight>

calls.name: proxy_vote
docs: Vote in a referendum on behalf of a stash. If `vote.is_aye()`, the vote is to enact
the proposal;  otherwise it is a vote to keep the status quo.
# <weight>
- One DB change, one DB entry.
# </weight>

calls.name: emergency_cancel
docs: Schedule an emergency cancellation of a referendum. Cannot happen twice to the same
referendum.

calls.name: external_propose
docs: Schedule a referendum to be tabled once it is legal to schedule an external
referendum.

calls.name: external_propose_majority
docs: Schedule a majority-carries referendum to be tabled next once it is legal to schedule
an external referendum.
Unlike `external_propose`, blacklisting has no effect on this and it may replace a
pre-scheduled `external_propose` call.

calls.name: external_propose_default
docs: Schedule a negative-turnout-bias referendum to be tabled next once it is legal to
schedule an external referendum.
Unlike `external_propose`, blacklisting has no effect on this and it may replace a
pre-scheduled `external_propose` call.

calls.name: fast_track
docs: Schedule the currently externally-proposed majority-carries referendum to be tabled
immediately. If there is no externally-proposed referendum currently, or if there is one
but it is not a majority-carries referendum then it fails.
- `proposal_hash`: The hash of the current external proposal.
- `voting_period`: The period that is allowed for voting on this proposal. Increased to
`EmergencyVotingPeriod` if too low.
- `delay`: The number of block after voting has ended in approval and this should be
enacted. This doesn't have a minimum amount.

calls.name: veto_external
docs: Veto and blacklist the external proposal hash.

calls.name: cancel_referendum
docs: Remove a referendum.

calls.name: cancel_queued
docs: Cancel a proposal queued for enactment.

calls.name: set_proxy
docs: Specify a proxy. Called by the stash.
# <weight>
- One extra DB entry.
# </weight>

calls.name: resign_proxy
docs: Clear the proxy. Called by the proxy.
# <weight>
- One DB clear.
# </weight>

calls.name: remove_proxy
docs: Clear the proxy. Called by the stash.
# <weight>
- One DB clear.
# </weight>

calls.name: delegate
docs: Delegate vote.
# <weight>
- One extra DB entry.
# </weight>

calls.name: undelegate
docs: Undelegate vote.
# <weight>
# </weight>

calls.name: clear_public_proposals
docs: Veto and blacklist the proposal hash. Must be from Root origin.

calls.name: note_preimage
docs: Register the preimage for an upcoming proposal. This doesn't require the proposal to be
in the dispatch queue but does require a deposit, returned once enacted.

calls.name: note_imminent_preimage
docs: Register the preimage for an upcoming proposal. This requires the proposal to be
in the dispatch queue. No deposit is needed.

calls.name: reap_preimage
docs: Remove an expired proposal preimage and collect the deposit.

events.name: Proposed
docs: A motion has been proposed by a public account.

events.name: Tabled
docs: A public proposal has been tabled for referendum vote.

events.name: ExternalTabled
docs: An external proposal has been tabled.

events.name: Started
docs: A referendum has begun.

events.name: Passed
docs: A proposal has been approved by referendum.

events.name: NotPassed
docs: A proposal has been rejected by referendum.

events.name: Cancelled
docs: A referendum has been cancelled.

events.name: Executed
docs: A proposal has been enacted.

events.name: Delegated
docs: An account has delegated their vote to another account.

events.name: Undelegated
docs: An account has cancelled a previous delegation operation.

events.name: Vetoed
docs: An external proposal has been vetoed.

events.name: PreimageNoted
docs: A proposal's preimage was noted, and the deposit taken.

events.name: PreimageUsed
docs: A proposal preimage was removed and used (the deposit was returned).

events.name: PreimageInvalid
docs: A proposal could not be executed because its preimage was invalid.

events.name: PreimageMissing
docs: A proposal could not be executed because its preimage was missing.

events.name: PreimageReaped
docs: A registered preimage was removed and the deposit collected by the reaper (last item).

constants.name: EnactmentPeriod
docs: The minimum period of locking and the period between a proposal being approved and enacted.
It should generally be a little more than the unstake period to ensure that
voting stakers have an opportunity to remove themselves from the system in the case where
they are on the losing side of a vote.

constants.name: LaunchPeriod
docs: How often (in blocks) new public referenda are launched.

constants.name: VotingPeriod
docs: How often (in blocks) to check for new votes.

constants.name: MinimumDeposit
docs: The minimum amount to be used as a deposit for a public referendum proposal.

constants.name: EmergencyVotingPeriod
docs: Minimum voting period allowed for an emergency referendum.

constants.name: CooloffPeriod
docs: Period in blocks where an external proposal may not be re-submitted after being vetoed.

constants.name: PreimageByteDeposit
docs: The amount of balance that must be deposited per byte of preimage stored.

items.name: Proposals
docs: The hashes of the active proposals.

items.name: ProposalOf
docs: Actual proposal for a given hash, if it's current.

items.name: Voting
docs: Votes on a given proposal, if it is ongoing.

items.name: ProposalCount
docs: Proposals so far.

items.name: Members
docs: The current members of the collective. This is stored sorted (just by value).

calls.name: set_members
docs: Set the collective's membership manually to `new_members`. Be nice to the chain and
provide it pre-sorted.
Requires root origin.

calls.name: execute
docs: Dispatch a proposal from a member using the `Member` origin.
Origin must be a member of the collective.

calls.name: propose
docs: # <weight>
- Bounded storage reads and writes.
- Argument `threshold` has bearing on weight.
# </weight>

calls.name: vote
docs: # <weight>
- Bounded storage read and writes.
- Will be slightly heavier if the proposal is approved / disapproved after the vote.
# </weight>

events.name: Proposed
docs: A motion (given hash) has been proposed (by given account) with a threshold (given
`MemberCount`).

events.name: Voted
docs: A motion (given hash) has been voted on by given account, leaving
a tally (yes votes and no votes given respectively as `MemberCount`).

events.name: Approved
docs: A motion was approved by the required threshold.

events.name: Disapproved
docs: A motion was not approved by the required threshold.

events.name: Executed
docs: A motion was executed; `bool` is true if returned without error.

events.name: MemberExecuted
docs: A single member did some action; `bool` is true if returned without error.

items.name: Proposals
docs: The hashes of the active proposals.

items.name: ProposalOf
docs: Actual proposal for a given hash, if it's current.

items.name: Voting
docs: Votes on a given proposal, if it is ongoing.

items.name: ProposalCount
docs: Proposals so far.

items.name: Members
docs: The current members of the collective. This is stored sorted (just by value).

calls.name: set_members
docs: Set the collective's membership manually to `new_members`. Be nice to the chain and
provide it pre-sorted.
Requires root origin.

calls.name: execute
docs: Dispatch a proposal from a member using the `Member` origin.
Origin must be a member of the collective.

calls.name: propose
docs: # <weight>
- Bounded storage reads and writes.
- Argument `threshold` has bearing on weight.
# </weight>

calls.name: vote
docs: # <weight>
- Bounded storage read and writes.
- Will be slightly heavier if the proposal is approved / disapproved after the vote.
# </weight>

events.name: Proposed
docs: A motion (given hash) has been proposed (by given account) with a threshold (given
`MemberCount`).

events.name: Voted
docs: A motion (given hash) has been voted on by given account, leaving
a tally (yes votes and no votes given respectively as `MemberCount`).

events.name: Approved
docs: A motion was approved by the required threshold.

events.name: Disapproved
docs: A motion was not approved by the required threshold.

events.name: Executed
docs: A motion was executed; `bool` is true if returned without error.

events.name: MemberExecuted
docs: A single member did some action; `bool` is true if returned without error.

items.name: Members
docs: The current elected membership. Sorted based on account id.

items.name: RunnersUp
docs: The current runners_up. Sorted based on low to high merit (worse to best runner).

items.name: ElectionRounds
docs: The total number of vote rounds that have happened, excluding the upcoming one.

items.name: VotesOf
docs: Votes of a particular voter, with the round index of the votes.

items.name: StakeOf
docs: Locked stake of a voter.

items.name: Candidates
docs: The present candidate list. Sorted based on account id. A current member can never enter
this vector and is always implicitly assumed to be a candidate.

calls.name: vote
docs: Vote for a set of candidates for the upcoming round of election.
The `votes` should:
- not be empty.
- be less than the number of candidates.
Upon voting, `value` units of `who`'s balance is locked and a bond amount is reserved.
It is the responsibility of the caller to not place all of their balance into the lock
and keep some for further transactions.
# <weight>
#### State
Reads: O(1)
Writes: O(V) given `V` votes. V is bounded by 16.
# </weight>

calls.name: remove_voter
docs: Remove `origin` as a voter. This removes the lock and returns the bond.
# <weight>
#### State
Reads: O(1)
Writes: O(1)
# </weight>

calls.name: report_defunct_voter
docs: Report `target` for being an defunct voter. In case of a valid report, the reporter is
rewarded by the bond amount of `target`. Otherwise, the reporter itself is removed and
their bond is slashed.
A defunct voter is defined to be:
- a voter whose current submitted votes are all invalid. i.e. all of them are no
longer a candidate nor an active member.
# <weight>
#### State
Reads: O(NLogM) given M current candidates and N votes for `target`.
Writes: O(1)
# </weight>

calls.name: submit_candidacy
docs: Submit oneself for candidacy.
A candidate will either:
- Lose at the end of the term and forfeit their deposit.
- Win and become a member. Members will eventually get their stash back.
- Become a runner-up. Runners-ups are reserved members in case one gets forcefully
removed.
# <weight>
#### State
Reads: O(LogN) Given N candidates.
Writes: O(1)
# </weight>

calls.name: renounce_candidacy
docs: Renounce one's intention to be a candidate for the next election round. 3 potential
outcomes exist:
- `origin` is a candidate and not elected in any set. In this case, the bond is
unreserved, returned and origin is removed as a candidate.
- `origin` is a current runner up. In this case, the bond is unreserved, returned and
origin is removed as a runner.
- `origin` is a current member. In this case, the bond is unreserved and origin is
removed as a member, consequently not being a candidate for the next round anymore.
Similar to [`remove_voter`], if replacement runners exists, they are immediately used.

calls.name: remove_member
docs: Remove a particular member from the set. This is effective immediately and the bond of
the outgoing member is slashed.
If a runner-up is available, then the best runner-up will be removed and replaces the
outgoing member. Otherwise, a new phragmen round is started.
Note that this does not affect the designated block number of the next election.
# <weight>
#### State
Reads: O(do_phragmen)
Writes: O(do_phragmen)
# </weight>

events.name: NewTerm
docs: A new term with new members. This indicates that enough candidates existed, not that
enough have has been elected. The inner value must be examined for this purpose.

events.name: EmptyTerm
docs: No (or not enough) candidates existed for this round.

events.name: MemberKicked
docs: A member has been removed. This should always be followed by either `NewTerm` ot
`EmptyTerm`.

events.name: MemberRenounced
docs: A member has renounced their candidacy.

events.name: VoterReported
docs: A voter (first element) was reported (byt the second element) with the the report being
successful or not (third element).

items.name: Members
docs: The current membership, stored as an ordered Vec.

calls.name: add_member
docs: Add a member `who` to the set.
May only be called from `AddOrigin` or root.

calls.name: remove_member
docs: Remove a member `who` from the set.
May only be called from `RemoveOrigin` or root.

calls.name: swap_member
docs: Swap out one member `remove` for another `add`.
May only be called from `SwapOrigin` or root.

calls.name: reset_members
docs: Change the membership to a new set, disregarding the existing membership. Be nice and
pass `members` pre-sorted.
May only be called from `ResetOrigin` or root.

calls.name: change_key
docs: Swap out the sending member for some other key `new`.
May only be called from `Signed` origin of a current member.

events.name: MemberAdded
docs: The given member was added; see the transaction for who.

events.name: MemberRemoved
docs: The given member was removed; see the transaction for who.

events.name: MembersSwapped
docs: Two members were swapped; see the transaction for who.

events.name: MembersReset
docs: The membership was reset; see the transaction for who the new set is.

events.name: KeyChanged
docs: One of the members' keys changed.

events.name: Dummy
docs: Phantom member, never used.

calls.name: final_hint
docs: Hint that the author of this block thinks the best finalized
block is the given number.

constants.name: WindowSize
docs: The number of recent samples to keep from this chain. Default is 101.

constants.name: ReportLatency
docs: The delay after which point things become suspicious. Default is 1000.

items.name: Authorities
docs: DEPRECATED
This used to store the current authority set, which has been migrated to the well-known
GRANDPA_AUTHORITES_KEY unhashed key.

items.name: State
docs: State of the current authority set.

items.name: PendingChange
docs: Pending change: (signaled at, scheduled change).

items.name: NextForced
docs: next block number where we can force a change.

items.name: Stalled
docs: `true` if we are currently stalled.

items.name: CurrentSetId
docs: The number of changes (both in terms of keys and underlying economic responsibilities)
in the "set" of Grandpa validators from genesis.

items.name: SetIdSession
docs: A mapping from grandpa set ID to the index of the *most recent* session for which its members were responsible.

calls.name: report_misbehavior
docs: Report some misbehavior.

events.name: NewAuthorities
docs: New authority set has been applied.

events.name: Paused
docs: Current authority set has been paused.

events.name: Resumed
docs: Current authority set has been resumed.

items.name: ProposalCount
docs: Number of proposals that have been made.

items.name: Proposals
docs: Proposals that have been made.

items.name: Approvals
docs: Proposal indices that have been approved but not yet awarded.

calls.name: propose_spend
docs: Put forward a suggestion for spending. A deposit proportional to the value
is reserved and slashed if the proposal is rejected. It is returned once the
proposal is awarded.
# <weight>
- Limited storage reads.
- One DB change, one extra DB entry.
# </weight>

calls.name: reject_proposal
docs: Reject a proposed spend. The original deposit will be slashed.
# <weight>
- Limited storage reads.
- One DB clear.
# </weight>

calls.name: approve_proposal
docs: Approve a proposal. At a later time, the proposal will be allocated to the beneficiary
and the original deposit will be returned.
# <weight>
- Limited storage reads.
- One DB change.
# </weight>

events.name: Proposed
docs: New proposal.

events.name: Spending
docs: We have ended a spend period and will now allocate funds.

events.name: Awarded
docs: Some funds have been allocated.

events.name: Burnt
docs: Some of our funds have been burnt.

events.name: Rollover
docs: Spending has finished; this is the amount that rolls over until next spend.

events.name: Deposit
docs: Some funds have been deposited.

constants.name: ProposalBond
docs: Fraction of a proposal's value that should be bonded in order to place the proposal.
An accepted proposal gets these back. A rejected proposal does not.

constants.name: ProposalBondMinimum
docs: Minimum amount of funds that should be placed in a deposit for making a proposal.

constants.name: SpendPeriod
docs: Period between successive spends.

constants.name: Burn
docs: Percentage of spare funds (if any) that are burnt per spend period.

items.name: GasSpent
docs: Gas spent so far in this block.

items.name: CurrentSchedule
docs: Current cost schedule for contracts.

items.name: PristineCode
docs: A mapping from an original code hash to the original code, untouched by instrumentation.

items.name: CodeStorage
docs: A mapping between an original code hash and instrumented wasm code, ready for execution.

items.name: AccountCounter
docs: The subtrie counter.

items.name: ContractInfoOf
docs: The code associated with a given account.

items.name: GasPrice
docs: The price of one unit of gas.

calls.name: update_schedule
docs: Updates the schedule for metering contracts.
The schedule must have a greater version than the stored schedule.

calls.name: put_code
docs: Stores the given binary Wasm code into the chain's storage and returns its `codehash`.
You can instantiate contracts only with stored code.

calls.name: call
docs: Makes a call to an account, optionally transferring some balance.
* If the account is a smart-contract account, the associated code will be
executed and any value will be transferred.
* If the account is a regular account, any value will be transferred.
* If no account exists and the call value is not less than `existential_deposit`,
a regular account will be created and any value will be transferred.

calls.name: instantiate
docs: Instantiates a new contract from the `codehash` generated by `put_code`, optionally transferring some balance.
Instantiation is executed as follows:
- The destination address is computed based on the sender and hash of the code.
- The smart-contract account is created at the computed address.
- The `ctor_code` is executed in the context of the newly-created account. Buffer returned
after the execution is saved as the `code` of the account. That code will be invoked
upon any call received by this account.
- The contract is initialized.

calls.name: claim_surcharge
docs: Allows block producers to claim a small reward for evicting a contract. If a block producer
fails to do so, a regular users will be allowed to claim the reward.
If contract is not evicted as a result of this call, no actions are taken and
the sender is not eligible for the reward.

events.name: Transfer
docs: Transfer happened `from` to `to` with given `value` as part of a `call` or `instantiate`.

events.name: Instantiated
docs: Contract deployed by address at the specified address.

events.name: CodeStored
docs: Code with the specified hash has been stored.

events.name: ScheduleUpdated
docs: Triggered when the current schedule is updated.

events.name: Dispatched
docs: A call was dispatched from the given account. The bool signals whether it was
successful execution or not.

events.name: Contract
docs: An event from contract of account.

constants.name: SignedClaimHandicap
docs: Number of block delay an extrinsic claim surcharge has.
When claim surcharge is called by an extrinsic the rent is checked
for current_block - delay

constants.name: TombstoneDeposit
docs: The minimum amount required to generate a tombstone.

constants.name: StorageSizeOffset
docs: Size of a contract at the time of instantiaion. This is a simple way to ensure that
empty contracts eventually gets deleted.

constants.name: RentByteFee
docs: Price of a byte of storage per one block interval. Should be greater than 0.

constants.name: RentDepositOffset
docs: The amount of funds a contract should deposit in order to offset
the cost of one byte.
Let's suppose the deposit is 1,000 BU (balance units)/byte and the rent is 1 BU/byte/day,
then a contract with 1,000,000 BU that uses 1,000 bytes of storage would pay no rent.
But if the balance reduced to 500,000 BU and the storage stayed the same at 1,000,
then it would pay 500 BU/day.

constants.name: SurchargeReward
docs: Reward that is received by the party whose touch has led
to removal of a contract.

constants.name: TransferFee
docs: The fee required to make a transfer.

constants.name: CreationFee
docs: The fee required to create an account.

constants.name: TransactionBaseFee
docs: The fee to be paid for making a transaction; the base.

constants.name: TransactionByteFee
docs: The fee to be paid for making a transaction; the per-byte portion.

constants.name: ContractFee
docs: The fee required to instantiate a contract instance. A reasonable default value
is 21.

constants.name: CallBaseFee
docs: The base fee charged for calling into a contract. A reasonable default
value is 135.

constants.name: InstantiateBaseFee
docs: The base fee charged for instantiating a contract. A reasonable default value

constants.name: MaxDepth
docs: The maximum nesting level of a call/instantiate stack. A reasonable default
value is 100.

constants.name: MaxValueSize
docs: The maximum size of a storage value in bytes. A reasonable default is 16 KiB.

constants.name: BlockGasLimit
docs: The maximum amount of gas that could be expended per block. A reasonable
default value is 10_000_000.

items.name: Key
docs: The `AccountId` of the sudo key.

calls.name: sudo
docs: Authenticates the sudo key and dispatches a function call with `Root` origin.
The dispatch origin for this call must be _Signed_.
# <weight>
- Limited storage reads.
- One DB write (event).
- Unknown weight of derivative `proposal` execution.
# </weight>

calls.name: set_key
docs: Authenticates the current sudo key and sets the given AccountId (`new`) as the new sudo key.
The dispatch origin for this call must be _Signed_.
# <weight>
- Limited storage reads.
- One DB change.
# </weight>

calls.name: sudo_as
docs: Authenticates the sudo key and dispatches a function call with `Signed` origin from
a given account.
The dispatch origin for this call must be _Signed_.
# <weight>
- Limited storage reads.
- One DB write (event).
- Unknown weight of derivative `proposal` execution.
# </weight>

events.name: Sudid
docs: A sudo just took place.

events.name: KeyChanged
docs: The sudoer just switched identity; the old key is supplied.

events.name: SudoAsDone
docs: A sudo just took place.

items.name: GossipAt
docs: The block number when we should gossip.

items.name: Keys
docs: The current set of keys that may issue a heartbeat.

items.name: ReceivedHeartbeats
docs: For each session index, we keep a mapping of `AuthIndex`
to `offchain::OpaqueNetworkState`.

items.name: AuthoredBlocks
docs: For each session index, we keep a mapping of `T::ValidatorId` to the
number of blocks authored by the given authority.

events.name: HeartbeatReceived
docs: A new heartbeat was received from `AuthorityId`

events.name: AllGood
docs: At the end of the session, no offence was committed.

events.name: SomeOffline
docs: At the end of the session, at least once validator was found to be offline.

items.name: Reports
docs: The primary structure that holds all offence records keyed by report identifiers.

items.name: ConcurrentReportsIndex
docs: A vector of reports of the same kind that happened at the same time slot.

items.name: ReportsByKindIndex
docs: Enumerates all reports of a kind along with the time they happened.
All reports are sorted by the time of offence.
Note that the actual type of this mapping is `Vec<u8>`, this is because values of
different types are not supported at the moment so we are doing the manual serialization.

events.name: Offence
docs: There is an offence reported of the given `kind` happened at the `session_index` and
(kind-specific) time slot. This event is not deposited for duplicate slashes.

items.name: RandomMaterial
docs: Series of block headers from the last 81 blocks that acts as random seed material. This
is arranged as a ring buffer with `block_number % 81` being the index into the `Vec` of
the oldest hash.

items.name: NameOf
docs: The lookup table for names.

calls.name: set_name
docs: Set an account's name. The name should be a UTF-8-encoded string by convention, though
we don't check it.
The name may not be more than `T::MaxLength` bytes, nor less than `T::MinLength` bytes.
If the account doesn't already have a name, then a fee of `ReservationFee` is reserved
in the account.
The dispatch origin for this call must be _Signed_.
# <weight>
- At most one balance operation.
- One storage read/write.
- One event.
# </weight>

calls.name: clear_name
docs: Clear an account's name and return the deposit. Fails if the account was not named.
The dispatch origin for this call must be _Signed_.
# <weight>
- One balance operation.
- One storage read/write.
- One event.
# </weight>

calls.name: kill_name
docs: Remove an account's name and take charge of the deposit.
Fails if `who` has not been named. The deposit is dealt with through `T::Slashed`
imbalance handler.
The dispatch origin for this call must be _Root_ or match `T::ForceOrigin`.
# <weight>
- One unbalanced handler (probably a balance transfer)
- One storage read/write.
- One event.
# </weight>

calls.name: force_name
docs: Set a third-party account's name with no deposit.
No length checking is done on the name.
The dispatch origin for this call must be _Root_ or match `T::ForceOrigin`.
# <weight>
- At most one balance operation.
- One storage read/write.
- One event.
# </weight>

events.name: NameSet
docs: A name was set.

events.name: NameForced
docs: A name was forcibly set.

events.name: NameChanged
docs: A name was changed.

events.name: NameCleared
docs: A name was cleared, and the given balance returned.

events.name: NameKilled
docs: A name was removed and the given balance slashed.

constants.name: ReservationFee
docs: Reservation fee.

constants.name: MinLength
docs: The minimum length a name may be.

constants.name: MaxLength
docs: The maximum length a name may be.
